description: Second term of a two-year sequence designed to integrate real world experiences into various Bioengienering Science courses. It is required for both BSE and BAS majors. It is intended for the spring semester of the Sophomore year.
name: BIOENGINEERING LAB II

values.comments:
BE210 is a sophomore-level laboratory course covering applications related to molecular biology, microfluidics and biomechanics. Strong emphasis is placed on instrumentation, measurement, data analysis methods and research design. This course incorporates a lecture series for presentation of relevant statistical applications and study designs as related to the experiments of the course. The course utilizes a team-approach to facilitate research and learning.

The class “exposes students to actual lab techniques employed in the field.” Students found the content of this course to be interesting, but the curriculum underdeveloped. Pre-lab assignments were time-consuming yet “rarely were enough to sufficiently prepare [students] for lab.” Lab procedures seemed “vague and often not very helpful,” resulting in experiments that yielded inevitably faulty results. Frustrated students commented that some labs “were not reasonable” for their skill level, “not practical for completion within the 6 hour time period,” and did not properly provide necessary background information.

It was noted that professors often “were not in class during the latter parts of the experiments,” often leaving their teaching duties to TAs, who “seemed [to have] very little knowledge of the experiments.” This led to inconclusive experiments in many cases. Dr. Winkelstein in particular was “extremely poor at communicating the course material effectively.”

Students found the course “time-consuming,” and the course grading “very subjective.” “The course needs a face lift,” noted one student; “the course has been a nightmare,” said another. It is not recommended that students who are not required to take this course enroll.

Strong emphasis is placed on instrumentation, measurement, data analysis methods and research design. This course incorporates a lecture series for presentation of relevant statistical applications and study designs as related to the experiments of the course. It was noted that professors often “were not in class during the latter parts of the experiments,” often leaving their teaching duties to TAs, who “seemed [to have] very little knowledge of the experiments.” This led to inconclusive experiments in many cases. Dr. Sarkar in particular seemed to be more “accessible to students” than her colleagues.

Students found the course “time consuming,” and the course grading “very subjective.” “The course needs a face lift,” noted one student; “the course has been a nightmare,” said another. It is not recommended that students who are not required to take this course enroll.
